data.value: The Laplacian matrix of a graph is sometimes referred to as the "Kirchhoff matrix" or just the "Laplacian", and is useful in many parts of spectral graph theory. In particular, the eigen-decomposition of the Laplacian can give insight into many properties of the graph, e.g., is commonly used for spectral data embedding and clustering.
The constructed Laplacian doubles the memory use if
or the matrix is sparse in the
format, or dense array, except for the integer input with
If the input adjacency matrix is not symmetic, the Laplacian is also non-symmetric unless
Diagonal entries of the input adjacency matrix are ignored and replaced with zeros for the purpose of normalization where
. The normalization uses the inverse square roots of row-sums of the input adjacency matrix, and thus may fail if the row-sums contain negative or complex with a non-zero imaginary part values.
The normalization is symmetric, making the normalized Laplacian also symmetric if the input csgraph was symmetric.
If True, then compute symmetrically normalized Laplacian. Default: False.
If True, then also return an array related to vertex degrees. Default: False.
If True, then use out-degree instead of in-degree. This distinction matters only if the graph is asymmetric. Default: False.
in place if possible, avoiding doubling the memory use. Default: True, for backward compatibility.
Determines the format of the output Laplacian:
'function' is a pointer to evaluating the Laplacian-vector   or Laplacian-matrix product;
'lo' results in the format of the
Choosing 'function' or 'lo' always avoids doubling the memory use, ignoring
The dtype of the output. If
, the dtype of the output matches the dtype of the input csgraph, except for the case
and integer-like csgraph, where the output dtype is 'float' allowing accurate normalization, but dramatically increasing the memory use. Default: None, for backward compatibility.

children.param: dtype: None or one of numeric numpy dtypes, optional

data.value: If True, then the output Laplacian is symmetric/Hermitian. The symmetrization is done by

without dividing by 2 to preserve integer dtypes if possible prior to the construction of the Laplacian. The symmetrization will increase the memory footprint of sparse matrices unless the sparsity pattern is symmetric or
is 'function' or 'lo'. Default: False, for backward compatibility.
The N x N Laplacian of csgraph. It will be a NumPy array (dense) if the input was dense, or a sparse matrix otherwise, or the format of a function or
The length-N main diagonal of the Laplacian matrix. For the normalized Laplacian, this is the array of square roots of vertex degrees or 1 if the degree is zero.
Return the Laplacian of a directed graph.
Our first illustration is the symmetric graph
has different row- and column sums, resulting in two varieties of the Laplacian matrix, using an in-degree, which is the default
Constructing a symmetric Laplacian matrix, one can add the two as
that is equivalent to symmetrizing the original graph

The goal of normalization is to make the non-zero diagonal entries of the Laplacian matrix to be all unit, also scaling off-diagonal entries correspondingly. The normalization can be done manually, e.g.,
which now instead of the diagonal returns the scaling coefficients
Zero scaling coefficients are substituted with 1s, where scaling has thus no effect, e.g.,
Only the symmetric normalization is implemented, resulting in a symmetric Laplacian matrix if and only if its graph is symmetric and has all non-negative degrees, like in the examples above.
The output Laplacian matrix is by default a dense array or a sparse matrix inferring its shape, format, and dtype from the input graph matrix:
but can alternatively be generated matrix-free as a LinearOperator:
The Laplacian matrix is used for spectral data clustering and embedding as well as for spectral graph partitioning. Our final example illustrates the latter for a noisy directed linear graph.
Create a directed linear graph with
vertices using a sparse adjacency matrix
and add a random sparse noise to the graph
The constant vector of ones is always a trivial eigenvector of the non-normalized Laplacian to be filtered out:
Alternating (1) the sign of the graph weights allows determining labels for spectral max- and min- cuts in a single loop. Since the graph is undirected, the option
must be used in the construction of the Laplacian. The option
cannot be used in (2) for the negative weights here as the symmetric normalization evaluates square roots. The option
in (2) is matrix-free, i.e., guarantees a fixed memory footprint and read-only access to the graph. Calling the eigenvalue solver

(3) computes the Fiedler vector that determines the labels as the signs of its components in (5). Since the sign in an eigenvector is not deterministic and can flip, we fix the sign of the first component to be always +1 in (4).

As anticipated for a (slightly noisy) linear graph, the max-cut strips all the edges of the graph coloring all odd vertices into one color and all even vertices into another one, while the balanced min-cut partitions the graph in the middle by deleting a single edge. Both determined partitions are optimal.

signature.value: laplacian(csgraph, normed=False, return_diag=False, use_out_degree=False, *, copy=True, form='array', dtype=None, symmetrized=False)
